title: Czech authorities drop case against prime minister
text:
Czech Republic's Prime Minister Andrej Babiš | Jack Taylor/Getty Images Czech authorities drop case against prime minister Concerns had been raised over use of EU funding for agriculture project.

A state attorney in Prague Friday formally dropped investigations into Prime Minister Andrej Babiš and several others in a case concerning the use of EU funds.

The project under investigation, a farm and hotel complex known as Stork’s Nest, correctly qualified as a small and medium-sized business for the purposes of receiving an EU subsidy, despite links to Babiš's conglomerate Agrofert, the prosecutor wrote in a statement.

Czech police had initially recommended the prime minister be charged with subsidy fraud for the €2 million in EU funds allocated to Stork’s Nest.

The case had garnered significant attention both in the Czech Republic and in Brussels, sparking protests in Prague and an investigation by the EU’s anti-fraud agency OLAF which detected irregularities in the project.

The prime minister has denied any wrongdoing.
